title: 110_hr1307
content: The "Veterans Identity Protection Act" or "VIP Act" aims to reimburse individuals for injuries resulting from unauthorized use of information from the Department of Veterans Affairs and expedite the settlement of claims for these injuries. The "Veterans Identity Protection Act" defines key terms such as Director and Injured person, who are individuals affected by compromised personal information from the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Veterans Identity Protection Act" defines the Office as the Office of Veterans Identity Protection Claims established under section 4(a). The Office of Veterans Identity Protection Claims is established under section 4 of the Veterans Identity Protection Act. The Office of Veterans Identity Protection Claims, established under the Veterans Identity Protection Act, is an independent office of the executive branch responsible for receiving, processing, and paying claims. The President appoints a director to investigate, consider, and determine money damages claims. The office is funded from allocated funds and can reimburse other agencies for support. Temporary personnel may be appointed as needed. The Office of Veterans Identity Protection Claims, established under the Veterans Identity Protection Act, can appoint personnel without following title 5, United States Code. The Director can request personnel from other federal departments on a reimbursable basis to assist in carrying out duties under the Act. SEC. 5. REIMBURSEMENT FOR INJURIES SUFFERED. Each injured person is entitled to reimbursement for injuries resulting from unauthorized use of personal information and damages determined by the Director. Claims must be submitted within 2 years of regulations being promulgated, and investigations will follow state laws unless specified otherwise in the Act. The Act specifies that state laws apply to calculating damages for injured persons. Payments are limited to compensatory damages and exclude punitive damages. The Director must determine and settle claims within 180 days of submission. The Director will determine if the claimant is an injured person, if the injury resulted from unauthorized use of personal information, and the amount to be paid under the Act. Payments are limited to compensatory damages to prevent excessive recovery. The Director may reduce the amount to be paid for a claim by the total of any payments or settlements made to the injured person. The Director can also make advance or partial payments before the final settlement of a claim, including on severable portions. If further payment is denied after a partial payment, the claimant has options. The claimant may seek judicial review under subsection (i) and keep any partial payment received, unless the Director determines eligibility or fraudulent procurement. Allowable damages under this Act may include uncompensated losses from unauthorized use of personal information. The acceptance of any payment under this Act by a claimant is final and releases all claims against the United States related to the same subject matter. The claimant must certify the claim as true and correct under penalty of perjury. The Director must publish interim final regulations for processing and payment of claims under this Act within 45 days of enactment. Additionally, a clear explanation in English and Spanish must be published in newspapers of general circulation in each state and the District of Columbia. The Director must disseminate a clear explanation of the rights and requirements under this Act through various media channels. Additionally, consultation with relevant federal and state authorities is required in administering this Act. An injured person may elect to seek reimbursement from the United States for injuries resulting from unauthorized use of personal information by submitting a claim under this Act, filing a claim under chapter 171 of title 28, or bringing a civil action under any other law. An injured person can seek reimbursement for unauthorized use of personal information by submitting a claim under this Act, filing a claim under chapter 171 of title 28, or bringing a civil action under any other law. An election to seek reimbursement in any manner described in paragraph (1) is final and conclusive on the claimant with respect to all injuries resulting from the unauthorized use of personal identifying information. The Director will establish arbitration procedures within 45 days of the enactment of this Act to settle disputes regarding claims submitted under this Act. An injured person can settle a disputed claim through arbitration under this Act, with the election being binding and precluding judicial review. This Act does not affect entitlements under Federal programs. Claimants aggrieved by the Director's decision can seek judicial review within 60 days. An injured person can settle a disputed claim through arbitration under this Act, with the election being binding and precluding judicial review. Claimants aggrieved by the Director's decision may bring a civil action in the United States District Court within 60 days to modify or set aside the decision. The court will hear the action based on the record before the Director, and the decision will be upheld if supported by substantial evidence. No attorney or agent can charge fees for services rendered in connection with a claim under this Act. An attorney or agent cannot charge fees exceeding 10 percent of the claim payment under this Act. Violators may be fined up to $10,000. Debt collection requirements under title 31, United States Code, do not apply to payments made under this Act. SEC. 6. REPORT; AUDIT. The Director must submit a report every six months to specified committees detailing claims under the Act, including amount claimed, nature of claim, and status. The Comptroller General will conduct an annual audit on all claims and report the results to the committees. The Director must report to committees every six months on claims under the Act. An annual audit will be conducted by the Comptroller General on all claims, with results reported to the committees within a year of the Act's enactment. Authorization of appropriations is granted to the Director to carry out the Act, with funds remaining available until expended.
